title: 107_hr772
content: The "Access to Aid Act of 2001" establishes a program under Title X of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 for innovative partnerships. The Secretary is authorized to establish a program to mentor college eligible students and their families on college selection, admissions, and funding, supporting them until the end of their college career. Nonprofit organizations will provide mentoring and outreach to promote enrollment of first-generation, low-income students in colleges nationwide. The program aims to shift the cost from the Federal Government to the private sector after 24 months, involve parents in college selection and admissions, and provide counseling services on college funding. The program aims to shift the cost from the Federal Government to the private sector after 24 months, involve parents in college selection and admissions, and provide counseling services on college funding. The program enables students to evaluate and select colleges based on their interests and qualifications, not cost, leading to a higher college graduation rate. It also includes an Emergency Grant Component that provides small grants for college visits, books, and equipment, and a Workshops Component that offers outreach support to school guidance staff. The organization will provide workshops on college admissions, funding, and financial aid to participating schools' staff and students. They will offer a minimum of 10 workshops at each project site. Implementation of program under SEC. 10995B. The program under SEC. 10995B involves the identification of participants nominated by high school staff based on college eligibility, first-generation, low-income status. Students selected for assistance must not have been served by TRIO or GEAR UP. Access aid is provided to students in each state by qualifying organizations that are tax-exempt, not affiliated with educational institutions, do not sell financial products, have experience in college admissions and funding, and are familiar with Federal outreach programs. To be eligible for a grant under this program, applicants must demonstrate familiarity with Federal outreach programs, prior experience with public secondary schools, evidence of demand from schools, a plan for shifting funding from public to private sectors, public awareness plan, counseling services plan for participants, and a quantifiable evaluation plan. Additionally, applicants must submit a plan for carrying out the program to the Secretary. The applicant must submit a plan to the Secretary outlining the program details, selection process for students and districts, services provided, and strategy for transitioning funding from the Federal Government to the private sector. The plan must describe the activities seeking assistance and provide assurances for compliance with program requirements. "SEC. 10995C. EARLY INTERVENTION." To receive payments, organizations must provide mentoring, outreach, and supportive services to promote enrollment of first-generation, low-income students in colleges. Services start in 10th grade and continue through college completion, focusing on college selection, admissions, and funding. Counseling involves parents or guardians and emphasizes selecting colleges based on fit rather than cost. The Secretary will establish criteria for using mentoring, counseling, outreach, and supportive services programs to meet program requirements. Organizations can contract certain services from other providers. $2,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006.
